m_DescList: Web crawling is a technology that collects webpage data through automated programs. The core steps are as follows:
1. Obtain raw HTML code of webpages via HTTP requests
2. Use regular expressions to match hyperlinks in HTML
3. Use regular expressions to locate text and data
4. Store cleaned text in databases or file systems
For example, below is a segment of HTML code:
<color=#804422><!DOCTYPE</color> <color=#ee3300>html</color><color=#804422>></color>
<color=#804422><html</color> <color=#ee3300>lang</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"en"</color><color=#804422>></color>
<color=#804422><head></color>
<color=#804422><meta</color> <color=#ee3300>charset</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"UTF-8"</color><color=#804422>></color>
<color=#804422><meta</color> <color=#ee3300>name</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"viewport"</color> <color=#ee3300>content</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"</color>>
<color=#804422><title></color>Document<color=#804422></title></color>
<color=#804422></head></color>
<color=#804422><body></color>
<color=#804422><a</color> <color=#ee3300>href</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"http://127.0.0.1"</color><color=#804422>></</color><color=#804422>a></color>
<color=#804422></body></color>
<color=#804422></html></color>
This HTML code consists of tags. For example, a body tag can be written as:
<color=#804422><body></color><color=#666666>some code here...</color><color=#804422></body></color>
<color=#804422><body></color> and <color=#804422></body></color> appear in pairs, with child element content written between the tag symbols.
For example, an a tag can be written as:
<color=#804422><a</color> <color=#ee3300>href</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"http://127.0.0.1"</color><color=#804422>></</color><color=#804422>a></color>
The middle section <color=#ee3300>href</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"http://127.0.0.1"</color> serves as an attribute of the a tag, indicating the URL the browser navigates to when clicking the link.
Some tags do not require pairs,
for example, a link tag can be written as:

<color=#804422><link </color><color=#ee3300>rel</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"stylesheet"</color> <color=#ee3300>href</color>=<color=#3c3cff>"/lib/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" </color><color=#804422>/></color>
Regardless of how tags vary in structure, a syntactically correct tag always has paired "<" and ">" enclosing it.
To simplify the problem difficulty, the following conventions are made:
1. Assume input HTML code is syntactically correct; every <color=#804422><a</color><color=#804422>></color> has a corresponding <color=#804422></a</color><color=#804422>></color>
2. Keywords (<color=#3c3cff>href id class</color> etc.) and tag names (<color=#3c3cff>a div span</color> etc.) are all lowercase
3. For 100% of input data, only <color=#3c3cff>"</color> is used, not a mix of <color=#3c3cff>" '</color>
4. The capture group for links is named url
5. For 100% of input data, there are no spaces after <color=#ee3300>href</color>
6. Special case: <color=#ee3300>href</color>=<color=#3c3cff>""</color> â€“ if href content is an empty string, do not match this a tag
Now, the goal is to match the content of a tags containing href.
<color=#666666>This problem is challenging; skip if you can't solve it...</color>
Please construct a regular expression that passes all tests on the right.
